unnormalised: Delhi chef's bizarre culinary creation goes viral!
normalised: Delhi chef's bizarre culinary creation goes viral!

unnormalised: A Delhi-based chef, known only as 'Chef Anand ji,' has sent social media into a frenzy with his latest recipe: Chai-infused Biryani. Yes, you read that right. According to his online post, the recipe calls for precisely 1.5 liters of strongly brewed masala chai to be added during the cooking process. He insists it enhances the aroma and adds a “unique Desi twist.”
normalised: A Delhi-based chef, known only as 'Chef Anand ji,' has sent social media into a frenzy with his latest recipe: Chai-infused Biryani. Yes, you read that right. According to his online post, the recipe calls for precisely one point five liters of strongly brewed masala chai to be added during the cooking process. He insists it enhances the aroma and adds a “unique Desi twist.”

unnormalised: Critics are, understandably, skeptical. “Chai and Biryani? That’s like mixing petrol and jalebi!” exclaimed a prominent food blogger. Initial taste tests have yielded mixed results, with one brave soul claiming it tasted "vaguely like sadness" and another saying it was "surprisingly not the worst thing I've eaten… today." The recipe also calls for 500 gms of basmati rice and a "generous pinch" of Chef Anand's "secret masala blend", the recipe for which he guards zealously.
normalised: Critics are, understandably, skeptical. “Chai and Biryani? That’s like mixing petrol and jalebi!” exclaimed a prominent food blogger. Initial taste tests have yielded mixed results, with one brave soul claiming it tasted "vaguely like sadness" and another saying it was "surprisingly not the worst thing I've eaten… today." The recipe also calls for five hundred grams of basmati rice and a "generous pinch" of Chef Anand's "secret masala blend", the recipe for which he guards zealously.

unnormalised: The post has already garnered over 10,000 comments, with many users expressing horror and disbelief. One user commented, "Is nothing sacred anymore? Next, he'll be putting ketchup in our sambar!" However, some adventurous foodies are planning to try the recipe, posting that they'll let everyone know "how bad (or surprisingly good) it is".
normalised: The post has already garnered over ten thousand comments, with many users expressing horror and disbelief. One user commented, "Is nothing sacred anymore? Next, he'll be putting ketchup in our sambar!" However, some adventurous foodies are planning to try the recipe, posting that they'll let everyone know "how bad (or surprisingly good) it is".

unnormalised: Chef Anand stands by his creation. "People are afraid of innovation! This isn't just Biryani; it's an experience," he declared in a recent interview, adding that it only takes roughly 45 mins to prep and cook. He estimates that the recipe yields enough for 4 servings. Whether this culinary experiment is a stroke of genius or a recipe for disaster, only time (and brave taste-testers) will tell!

This isn't just Biryani; it's an experience," he declared in a recent interview, adding that it only takes roughly forty five minutes to prep and cook. He estimates that the recipe yields enough for four servings. Whether this culinary experiment is a stroke of genius or a recipe for disaster, only time (and brave taste-testers) will tell!
